prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral set-up is motivated in the Scientific Justification. We include a broad continuum band. We use other basebands to search for molecular lines. We need relatively broad velocity coverage for outflow tracers such as 12CO and H(30)alpha. Finer velocity resolution is desired for dense gas / hot core / disk tracers.
The spectral set-up has been set to be identical to that of the companion proposal.

We wish to observe at the highest angular resolution possible to see the finest details possible around massive protostars. This choice sets the range of angular scales in this observation to those of the C34-8 configuration.

Our sensitivity goal is 0.05mJy at 234GHz, which is described in the Scientific Justification. It would allow substructures to be detected at high significance (>4 sigma) within the currently best resolution image of dust continuum emission from G35.2N, given the observed flux from a ~0.4" beam.
Correlator set-up: see first science goal.
Spatial requirements: see first science goal.
Sensitivity requirements: see first science goal. [uniform sensitivity desired in the survey]

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA now has the ability to see fine details around massive protostars. Observing dust continuum and lines at 1.3mm, we aim to detect substructure, especially multiplicity and disk structures, in a sample of 8 high-mass protostellar cores at scales down to ~70 AU. This sample has been selected as part of a larger group being observed at MIR to FIR wavelengths with SOFIA. Sophisticated radiative transfer models are being utilized to test the geometries of dust structures, especially outflow cavities, via this infrared emission. The mm continuum observations with ALMA will complement these studies by probing colder, high column density structures at much finer resolution. The results of this project have the potential to provide definitive tests of massive star formation theories, since these make widely varying predictions on the degree of primordial multiplicity during massive star formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.01454, The Structure of Massive Protostellar Cores, Yichen Zhang
